column4: Hi everyone, I've got a very weird issue here, that I don't know how to fix.  In windows my CPU fan works just fine, but in linux it never powers down to a near-stop like it does in windows.  It can get louder when there's lots of heat, but not as quiet as it is in windows.  Any suggestions?
Turn off ACPI at boot (never start it)
how do you do that?  Bios, or?
No, with your system startup tool, you click to uncheck the button
and this will make the fans behave properly?
System->Administration->Services ?
Do you have an IBM computer ?
Not that I know of.
What do you have ?
apmd too/
what exactly will this do?
update-rc.d -f acpi remove" (or acpid or whatever yould like) ,... first test with shutting it down manually (/etc/init.d/apci stop)
yes, but what wil it do?
remove all links to the startup scripts so that they wont be startrted at boot, use "update-rc.d -f acpid default" to start it
no no.  What will removing ACPI do, exactly?
it will remiove the startup links, not remove any vital thing you cannot activate again
you're skirting my question.
quit bullshitting a coder since 1997
Either you listen or you dont
What will disabling ACPI do, exactly?
Not handle acpi calls
Such as 'starrt your fans and run them warm' etc
